channel.title: The crash page
channel.description:
Well, when the forums crash we all know that the error page looks like: "Unable to connect to database" etc, doesn't anyone get sick of seeing that? Couldn't mopar please fix it?
Or, change it to something that is less-frustrating than that page: perhaps very fkn hot porn. Now THAT would be a good error page, and I would try to get the staff to crash it as much as possible >:)
Thus my theory: People flame at this forum because they're all angry from seeing that page.

item.title: The crash page
item.dc:creator: @ada ada
item.description:
@ada wrote:

Something needs to happen to the moparisthebest.com website Maybe it needs to be shutdown, maybe it needs a complete overhaul. Mopar should consider just separating the thing altogether. It might stop the onslaught of moparscape noobs going onto moparisthebest and posting. If they sign up at moparscape when the forums are separate, it’s a lot harder to make the “mistake” of posting on the wrong one, because they won’t have an account here unless they sign up separately.

Really, if mopar doesn’t want to get rid of moparscape, it at least needs overhauling. Maybe seperating the forums is the way to go in this case.

Read full topic

item.title: The crash page
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“BAsh(CntLgn), post:3, topic:208964”]The reason why it is down so much is apparently becuase the database is too big. So when it crashes it takes a while to startup. Not much we can do about that.

What we can do is prevent it from crashing in the first place. So why the hell doesn’t he look at the error logs and fix this?[/quote]
Unless MITB is running his mysql db on some pathetic hardware, it’s certainly not because the actual database is TOO BIG.
There can’t be more than two million rows in the db, and that is relatively small to some of the enterprise scale mysql DBs that are out there. MySQL was designed for querying massive amounts of data extremely quickly.
Which leaves it to a software problem (smf) or a hardware problem (apache/mysql being overloaded, eating into swap).

Last night I saw a “Server is shutting down” message, then a “can’t connect to database” message. Did someone reboot the server?

Read full topic
